releaseNotes.description: MBX 1.3 contains numerous improvements, mostly to performance.

changelog: Added a variety of new configuration options to enable optional optimizations.

Evaluation of MB-pol 2- and 3-body PIPs can now use SIMD instructions if enabled with new configuration options. Depending on your hardware, this produces anywhere between a 1.25x and 2.0x overall speed-up for the entire MB-pol PEF.
Refactored dispersion and Lennard-Jones to be more efficient on large boxes.
Intel Threading Building Blocks library can be used if enabled with new configuration options, significantly improving performance on large boxes.
Intel intrinsic math functions can now be used if enabled with new configuration options, significantly improving performance on large boxes.
Many small improvements to OpenMP parallelism.
Many small performance improvements, including many that are most impactful on large boxes.
Can now specify the 2-body PIP cutoff separately from the real-space cutoff used for dispersion and electrostatics.

releaseNotes.description: MBX version 1.2 has been released containing significant performance improvements! When running on many OpenMP threads, your many-body simulations may be up to 3-4x as fast! (depending, of course, on your particular hardware)

changelog: Improved ability to exploit OpenMP parallelism throughout MBX, particularly in the reciprocal space electrostatics and polynomial evaluation.
Reduced number of particles passed from LAMMPS interface to real space dispersion.

releaseNotes.description: MBX version 1.1 has been released containing significant performance improvements, specifically in the real-space electrostatics part of the PEF.

changelog: Significant performance improvements to the real-space electrostatics part of the PEF.
Added bin/mb_decomp executable, generated by make install when compiling stand-alone MBX. This executable can be used to perform many-body decomposition of input structures.
